yeah azureus lets you seed automatically i think

Most (all?) clients throw the torrent into the seeding column after downloading.  You can just leave it there to seed back.  If you want listen to the music after finishing your download, then stop the torrent first before copying the folder of music to another location on your computer, then restart the torrent.  If you stop the torrent and play the music without copying, you may not be able to seed because the client will say that another application is accessing the files.  If this happens, you can restart your computer and it will seed again (I use Azureus and it will not lose any torrents, even if my computer crashes).  

If you accidentally remove the torrent, just come back to this page and hit the download link.  If the files are in the same place, your client will recognize them and check them before putting them back in the seeding column.  Pixies rule!

@ seeders

It isn't necessary to seed but it sure is polite!  All you have to do is leave your torrent on and do not delete the files or the torrent file.  Most torrent programs seed automatically.  

You don't have to seed every torrent you have either.  If your list gets too long for your bandwidth to handle just check your ratio (it's one of the columns further to the right).  If you have a ratio of 1 or more that means you have uploaded as much as you have downloaded of that file.  I usually seed until I max out bandwidth (or get a call from my isp :D).
